summary: This is an affidavit filed by an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, certifying that the government and defense counsel could not agree on a two-week extension for producing documents from Jeffrey Epstein's electronic devices. The filing details the defense's conditions for consenting to the extension and the government's partial agreement.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) for which this affidavit regarding discovery deadlines is filed.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, whose office the affiant works for.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The individual from whom electronic devices were seized; the documents to be produced are extracted from his devices.

connections.description: Maxwell is the defendant in a case involving evidence seized from Epstein's electronic devices, indicating their alleged association in criminal activity.
Strauss is the Acting U.S. Attorney whose office is prosecuting Maxwell, establishing an adversarial legal relationship.

events.title: Government Requests Extension
events.description: The Government asked defense counsel whether they would consent to a two-week extension for producing documents from Epstein's devices.

events.title: Defense Presents Conditions
events.description: Defense counsel indicated they would consent to the extension only if four conditions were met, including extending motion deadlines and providing victim names.

events.title: Original Extended Production Deadline
events.description: The proposed new deadline for the production of documents from Epstein's electronic devices, which was the subject of the failed negotiation.

keyFacts: The government sought a two-week extension (to November 23, 2020) to produce documents from Jeffrey Epstein's seized electronic devices.
Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel would only consent to the extension under four conditions, including extending motion deadlines and providing the names of three minor victims from the indictment.
The government agreed to extend motion deadlines and provide Maxwell a laptop for discovery review in jail, but refused to provide victim names or all Jencks Act material by the proposed deadline.
The affidavit confirms the parties reached an impasse, requiring the government to file this certification with the court.
The document references 'three Minor Victims listed in the Indictment,' indicating the core charges involve alleged harm to minors.
